name: Supreme Commander
description: For a thousand years, three opposing forces have waged war for what they believe is true. There can be no room for compromise: their way is the only way. Dubbed The Infinite War, this devastating conflict has taken its toll on a once-peaceful galaxy and has only served to deepen the hatred between the factions.

reviews.review_text: I have now bought this game three times. I bought it on release for full price, lost the disk, rebought the game on disc a few years later, thats been lost forever, and i bought it a THIRD time and i still feel that i havent spent enough money to justify all the entertainment i've gotten from this game over the years. That tells you all you need to know, this is one of the best RTS games of all time. I've always thought Total Annihilation was the most underrated RTS ever made, and this spiritual successor does it even better. I will play this game in 20 years just like how i still play Total Annihilation even to this day.  You didnt come here to find out how the game plays, you want to know if its worth it or not. Well, this game has been out for a long time. All the info is already there for you. If you are a casual RTS fan, love giant robots and armies, enjoy building gigantic sprawling bases and high level strategy, all mixed with a decent to solid single player campaign, and great balance, you should definitely get this game, especially on sale.  Forged Alliance, the expansion, is also great and has the most players playing multiplayer. But to me the original will always hold a special place in my heart. Plus it seems more stable and the 4th race never quite felt as fluid or fun as the original three.  My third favorite RTS ever after SC:BW and DoW: Dark Crusade / Soulstorm.  UEF for life  10/10

This game is amazing, no doubt about it.  I first discovered this game when my dad gave it to me as a gift, he had never played it so he though I might show some interest in it. I booted up the game from the disc and played campaign, after the first mission I fell in love with it instantly. I learned the controls and fucntions pretty easily and played for hours on end; making planetfall, constructing a base and an army, and took down the opposing commander(s). Although games can be pretty long and tedious to complete, it is still fun trying to protect yourself from onslaughts of planes, ships, and tanks while trying to create your own army. Multiplayer is just like campaign/skirmish: great gameplay, great fun, and with real people to play with or against. It is sad that this game doesn't get the credit that it deserves and that it isn't as popular as It should be, because this game has been a fantastic experience playing.  1000000/10 Would always recommend

You can build your ground forces, naval, and air forces in one map and is one of the greatest RTS games has to offer. If you play RTS before, then this should be more interesting. I don't recommend this game unless you really enjoy turtling. It has good ideas, but they are poorly implemented. Painfully slow build times on units and structures, mass fabricators destroying any need to control the map and the resources scattered across it, and incredibly powerful defenses turn this into a painful slog. The ability to control and upgrade the commander who represents you in the game is neat at first, but they quickly become the big can which sits in the middle of its defense riddled, mass fabricator clogged base and never leaves. Because if the commander does leave, it runs a good chance of dying and losing the match.   What the game offers:  The Basics    You play as a commander aligned with one of three factions which can build basic structures. The factories let you get fabricators which build even better structures. Upgrade the factories to get better fabricators for better structures and units. You also need to balance production with your resource income, so make sure you're building mass pumps, power generators, and mass fabricators to meet your base's growing needs.   When it comes to crushing the opposition, you are given many options, and your three starting ones are land units, naval units, and air units. At higher fabricator tiers, you can get long range artillery, stealth, experimental units, and strategic missle launchers (nukes). Of course, all of this can be countered easily at lower cost by defenses. In order to defeat an enemy, you need to either catch their commander while it's exposed or have an overwhelming advantage to push through their defenses.  Mass pumps provide the most mass at the lowest energy cost, but they can only be built atop mass deposits scattered across the map. Ideally, the game would become a battle to control and defend mass pumps for a production edge over the opponent. Sadly, mass fabricators destroy this by allowing a player to acquire all of the mass they will ever need from the comfort and safety of their own base, often at a faster pace and at less expense.  The factions are almost entirely aesthetics, with their only major differences being what experimental units they can build. They all have the same unit classes and structures which do the same jobs. There are small bits of fluff like 'Aeon bomber does damage over (a very short) time, cybran bomber does slightly less damage over a slightly larger area, and UEF is a typical bomber with a large explosion and good damage.' But ultimately the differences are minimal.    Three Campaigns    The story is decent in each of the three races' campaigns, but the basics makes them a slow mess. Even the first map in the campaign takes at least forty minutes to finish simply because of how long it takes to build everything and amass enough firepower to win. And it only goes down hill from there. Expect one to two hours for each campaign map.    Skirmishes with AI's    These often take just as long as the campaign maps, although tech rushing (spending all of your resources on obtaining max tech units and structures as quickly as possible) can end an AI opponent quickly. It is impossible to beat the AI at spamming mass fabricators, so be prepared for a long slog if the battle isn't ended quickly. The AI skirmishes also seem to be buggy and occasionally crash to desktop for me, so beware.    Multiplayer    As other reviews have stated, look at Forged Alliances if you want an active online community. I haven't tried it, but from what I have read online, expect cheese.   This game may be worth buying on sale. If you're really liking some of these ideas, I'd recommend Planetary Annihilation when it is on sale instead if you don't mind its lack of a story filled campaign. It uses a large number of the same ideas in Supreme Commander, but is a better tuned experience overall.

If you've played Total Annihilation, you'll know the basics of how this game works already. And yet, this spiritual successor improves upon its unique RTS formula in almost every way possible. The price was worth it just for the single player campaigns, and I haven't even touched multiplayer yet. There's a simple hierarchy of 4 tiers and gives you so many options in combat. Unlimited resources (in a manner of speaking) lets you do more than other RTS games would. Even though Starcraft 1 and 2 are my favourite RTS games ever, this game is very refreshing in comparison with the freedom you have. You can turtle effectively with an impenetrable base and use long range nuclear missiles or artillery battery to destroy your opponent. You can send a swarm of 200 gunships to take them out. Or use an army of Tier 3 siege bots and AA bots. And you can use aircraft, land units and naval units. Then there's the unique, experimental units which take a lot of effort to build but are very fun to watch wrecking things. And let's not forget the ability to zoom out or in to almost any degree you feel like. The main campaigns are good and fun, even though the pacing could be a little better. I'd like to use the tier 3 siege bots, battleships and gunships a bit earlier. And you don't get to use the experimental units until halfway through the last mission- which is a little disappointing. There are only a few things I would say are bad about the game. Compared to Starcraft, it feels a lot slower. You need air transport to get your engineers anywhere other than your main base in an acceptable time fashion. Queing orders when selecting multiple units sometimes results in them repeating builds that have already been done, wasting precious time. The campaign also has an annoying unit limit that applies to buildings as well, and there's no quick way to delete units if need be. A simple 'delete' command would have been nice. Commanding armies has advanced controls but the units themselves still bump into each other and not attack as a clumped group (like Starcraft 2 handles very well). Projectiles operate in an immersive way, with bullets or missiles homing or not depending on the unit, but some units are nearly impossible to kill efficiently without transporting engineers and building defenses (tier 3 air superiority, ugh). The graphics are very impressive considering how old the game is, and I still like zooming in to inspect all the high tech lights and power networks I construct. My life for the Aeon Illuminate!

Air cover is only as good as the lack of air defenses allows, and offensives are bloody, attrition-style affairs. Resource management is very important, and who controls the best industrial base wins.   Buy this, and play it. The epic scale of the battles alone will stupefy and amaze.
